boardgame.name: Journey to Newhome
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Journey to Newhome is a series of short adventures designed for the Darwin’s World post-apocalyptic role-playing game. The adventures in this book are based around characters first introduced in the novel, Burning Lands. Journey to Newhome continues the story of several of those characters, but in a format usable in the Darwin’s World role-playing game. You will find usable game statistics for the book's major characters, as well as an overview of what happened to those characters after the events described in the novel.

More than just a write-up of stat blocks, however, Journey to Newhome provides usable adventures in the format of a protracted campaign of far-reaching consequences, though with some modification each adventure can be played individually as a short diversion or a single night’s challenge.

Journey to Newhome is composed of eight adventures that tell the story of a heroic new beginning for the people of the Twisted Earth. These adventures are set approximately ten years after the events described in the Darwin's World novel, Burning Lands, and also weaves in elements of other Darwin's World adventures (such as Halidom and the Mind Masters series). Each installment in the campaign features one or more characters (either directly or indirectly) from the novel; during the course of the campaign the player characters get a chance to meet these figures, deal with them, possibly fight them, and in some circumstances, adventure alongside them.

Product Highlights:

8 Part adventure path
23 Color Maps
Appendix of new gear, NPCs, and terrors

boardgame.name: Catacomb 3-D
Catacomb 3-D: A New Dimension
Catacomb 3-D: The Descent
Catacomb 3D
Catacombs 3
boardgame.description:
Catacomb 3-D (also known as Catacomb 3-D: A New Dimension, Catacomb 3-D: The Descent and Catacombs 3) is the third in the Catacomb series of video games (created by the founders of id Software), and the first of these games to feature 3D computer graphics. The game was originally published by Softdisk under the Gamer's Edge label, and is a first-person shooter with a dark fantasy setting. The player takes control of the high wizard Pelton Everhail in his quest to defeat the evil Gremlinar, also known as Nemesis.

Catacomb 3-D is a landmark title in terms of first-person graphics. The game was released in November 1991 and is arguably the first example of the modern, character-based first-person shooter genre, or at least it was a direct ancestor to the games that popularized the genre. It was released for the MS-DOS with EGA graphics. The game introduced the concept of showing the player's hand in the three-dimensional viewport, and an enhanced version of its technology was later used for the more successful and well-known Wolfenstein 3D. The game's more primitive technological predecessor was Hovertank 3D.

Source: Wikipedia, "Catacomb 3-D", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Game Documentation

You are Petton Everhail, High wizard of Thoria, the most powerful living wizard in the world and you've got a problem. The evil lich Grelminar, undead for over 200 years, has imprisoned Nemesis of Kelquest. (Nemesis is troublesome, but he's the only accessible person that can walk the Wildways, the super-natural paths to other dimensions.) Even you, an archmage, cannot travel to the places that Nemesis can. And so you journey to retrieve his body, now frozen in magical amber but still alive, from Grelminar's Keep on the dark island off the coast of Garacy. You had best be careful, or you'll be Grelminar's next prize. . .

Cat & Chocolate: Business Is Business can be played as a standalone game or combined with Cat & Chocolate. Instead of the original game's haunted mansion theme, Business Is Business revolves around wacky situations that arise from a life in the corporate world.

Each turn, the player draws an event and tells the story of how she would avoid disaster with up to 1-3 item cards in her hand. It's a test of the player's imagination and life experience!

Should your story be accepted by at least half of the other players, you get to keep the event card and play continues until a special event card called "End!" is revealed. Whoever has scored the most event cards wins.

What are roleplaying games and where are they played? Are history recreation and LARPing the same thing? Can roleplaying be dangerous?

Even though roleplaying games have been played in Finland for about thirty years, the hobby still raises questions and is relatively unknown to many. Roolipelaaminen - Eläytymistä ja fantasiaharrastusverkostoja offers a compact infopackage about the polymorphic world of roleplaying games. boardgame.name: Star Trek (Script Game)
boardgame.description:
UNLICENSED GAME




This game represents an unlicensed use of elements of the Star Trek franchise.




Star Trek was a text-based mainframe computer game written by Don Daglow on a PDP-10 timesharing computer at Pomona College in 1972, and upgraded periodically through 1974, including contributions by Jonathan Osser. The game was picked up by the DECUS user group in 1972 and distributed to many universities and other PDP-10 installations around the world, often appearing alongside the ASCII text game Star Trek.

The two Star Trek games were among the most popular mainframe computer games of the 1970s and could be played for free on college computer systems. The script game did not use a graphic sector/quadrant display as was used in the other popular Star Trek game. Instead, it described the action by generating a "script" of dialogue in traditional dramatic format using the names of Enterprise crew members from the popular television series.

Play begins with the player entering a name for the ship's captain. Spock then declares that a Klingon, Romulan or Tholian vessel has appeared on the Enterprise's sensors, and announce its position. On each turn, Sulu or Chekov provide updates on the enemy's position and Uhura asks for the player's orders.

The player issues orders by entering a number (initially from 1 to 10, later as high as 19 as additional orders were added to the code) to tell the crew of the Enterprise what to do. Additional data might need to be entered depending on the particular order. Options include moving closer or farther away from the enemy vessel, and firing phasers or photon torpedoes. The different weapons each have optimal ranges.

After each player turn the results are announced by Spock and then the enemy moves, fires or takes other action. Damage to shields, weapons and engines is reported, as well as the rising count of Enterprise casualties.

Source: Wikipedia, "Star Trek (script game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Unsun karuta
うんすんかるた
boardgame.description:
A traditional Japanese trick-taking card game based on the European game Ombre (originally "l'Hombre"), played with a special 75-card five-suited deck. This deck developed from Tenshō karuta, itself a close copy of the 48-card traditional Portuguese cards called "dragon cards" due to the dragons holding the suit symbols in the aces. Its creation was prompted by a ban on the older form of playing cards after Japan closed off the contact with the Western world in 1633, and became critical towards everything of European origin. Sunkun karuta took this game one step further.

The deck contains all 48 cards from Tenshō karuta; these are supplemented by introducing a fifth suit and increasing the number of cards in each suit from twelve to fifteen. Most additions refer to Japanese and Chinese culture, presumably a conscious choice intended to downplay the European origins of the game.

The suits are はう (hau), "flower" based on Portuguese 'paus' meaning "clubs", いす (isu) a shortened form of 'espadas' or "swords", こっぷ (koppu) from 'copas' or "cups", おうる (ōru) from 'ouros' or "coins" (literally "golds") and finally the added ぐる (guru) with the traditional Japanese 三つ巴 (mitsudomoe) sign as suit symbol. As in the European predecessor games, higher-numbered pip cards beat lower ones only in the former two suits, while the latter ones are "reversed".

The "dragon aces" are split into two distinct ranks by reintroducing a normal "one" in each suit and separate from the ろばい (robai) or "dragon" which normally ranks right above the ones. Above the number cards (1–9 plus robai) there are five court cards. From low to high, these are: そうた (sōta) "queen", うま (uma) "horse", きり (kiri) "soldier" (originally a king), うん (un) various Japanese mythological figures and すん (sun) various Chinese officials. The latter two ranks give the game its name. In the trump suit, the robai is promoted to above the kiri and the sōta above this again, except that the robai of hau is a permanent trump which is the fourth highest regardless of which suit is trump.

boardgame.name: Monopolino
Monopolino Disney
boardgame.description:
Object of the game: be the richest player when the game ends. The game ends when a player runs out of money.

How to play: every player take 10 houses (14 for 2 players). Every player takes 5x1000, 4x2000, 3x3000, 1x4000 1x5000. Players roll the dice to move.

If movement ends on a space without house: the player pays the bank the sum written on the space and becomes the owner. Players that end their turn on this space pay the owner the same sum. If the owner owns all houses on spaces of the same color the sum will be double.

If movement ends on the GO space: the player takes 2000 from bank.

If the movement ends on STATION space: reroll the dice and move again.

If the movement ends on RISK space: draw a card from the deck and follow the instructions.

If the movement ends on CAKE and BALLOON space: the player puts 2000 on LOTTERY space.

If the movement ends on LOTTERY space: the player takes all money on the space.

If the movement ends on GO TO SHOOTING GALLERY space: the player puts 3000 on LOTTERY space and goes on SHOOTING GALLERY space without passing the GO space.

RISK cards with HOUSE written: the player puts his house on a same color space written on card. If all of the same colour boxes are occupied by one player, the player has to draw another card. If the boxes are occupied by different players, the player replaces the home with their own.

boardgame.name: Veletas
boardgame.description:
Introduction

Veletas is a drawless territory game for two players: Black and White. It is played on the spaces (squares) of a 10x10 checkered square board, which is initially empty. Apart from the board, the necessary material comprises seven shooters and a sufficient number of black and white stones.

Both players control a number of neutral red pieces and shoot stones of their own colour from them. In order to win, a player must claim a majority of neutral pieces by having them surrounded by larger groups of their own pieces than their opponent's.

This game won (along with Four) the BoardGameGeek Best Combinatorial 2-Player Game of 2013 Award.



Definitions

A piece is a shooter, a black stone or a white stone.

A group is a set of one or more like-colored, orthogonally adjacent stones. The size of a group is the number of stones in it. Stones on top of shooters are not part of any groups.

A trapped shooter is a shooter that cannot make any legal move in the current position.



Play

The first player begins by placing three shooters and one black stone on empty squares of the board. The second player then chooses which player will be Black and which will be White. Next, White places the remaining four shooters and one white stone on empty squares of the board. In both cases, no shooters can be placed on the perimeter of the board. This restriction does not apply to the rest of the game.

From then on, the players take turns, starting with Black. On your turn, you may (but are not obliged to) move a shooter to an empty square in a straight orthogonal or diagonal line, without jumping over any stones. Then, you must place a stone of your color on an empty square that is a straight orthogonal or diagonal line away from the square onto which the shooter was moved (or from any shooter, if none was moved), with no stones in between along that line. This is called shooting. Claimed shooters (see below) cannot move or shoot. Note shooters can move and shoot over claimed or unclaimed shooters.

After shooting, if there are any trapped shooters on the board that have not been claimed before, each one of them is claimed by the player who owns the biggest group orthogonally adjacent to it. If there is no such group or the biggest such groups of each color are the same size, the shooter is claimed by the opponent. Claiming a shooter is indicated by placing a stone of the corresponding color on top of it. Claimed shooters remain unchanged for the rest of the game.

The game ends when a player has claimed the majority of shooters, i.e. at least four of them. That player wins. Draws are not possible.



Smaller versions

For shorter but still reasonable games, the following variants are suggested:


7x7 board with three shooters. The first player places one shooter, and White places the other two. Whoever claims two shooters wins.



9x9 board with five shooters. The first player places two shooters, and White places the other three. Whoever claims three shooters wins.


Online Play


Board Game Arena (real-time, turn-based)
Boardspace.net (real-time, AI option)


Mobile Apps

Boardspace.net local multiplayer or online, IOS
Boardspace.net local multiplayer or online, Android

boardgame.name: Die Reisende Kaiserin
boardgame.description:
[from the back of the book]
The court of the Empress: a place of authority, chivalry, intrigue. The grandees of the kingdom spend time at the court of Rohajas to bask in the glory of the empire of Raul, and also to exert tangible political power. It takes no wonder that the rulers of Aventuria face the courtyard of the Middle Empire and send ambassadors, diplomats and spies to feel the pulse of the Empire. But the court is not only a place of authority. It is home to the Empress and her family, surrounded by nobles and commoners, knights and courtiers, advisors and sycophants. But it is at it's brightest splendor, when the nobles of the kingdom shall be summoned to the court day to decide the fate of the empire, when tents and halls become places of representation.

Since the imperial court started the eternal journey, it moves from Palatinate to Palatinate, from county to county to bring shine and power to places far from the old imperial city of Gareth. And the call that sends many ministers into sleepless nights lets simple people and the young knights tremble alike with anticipation: "The Empress is coming!"

Die Reisende Kaiserin (The traveling Empress) presents the Imperial Court of the Middle Empire , with its officials and dignitaries , as well as its heroes and villains. In this sourcebook you will find a comprehensive overview of the actors on the court as well as a collection of palaces and imperial fortresses, and a typical meeting of the nobles in the peaceful city of Ragath in Almada.

boardgame.name: Relic Expedition: Villages and Markets Expansion
boardgame.description:
This expansion contains two new types of jungle tiles: villages and markets. Villages contain relics for which players must trade supplies; they make some relics more costly to obtain, and they give players a reason to carry duplicate supplies. Markets contain supplies for which players must trade relics; they give players another way to obtain the supplies they need, and they give players the opportunity to remove from the game a relic that their opponents need.

Contains 4 Market Tiles and 4 Village Tiles, one additional standard supply token of each type (marked with red text), a second additional First Aid supply token and a second additional Machete supply token (both also marked with red text), and 9 green triangular curse tokens.

boardgame.name: When Worlds Collide: A Role-Playing Game
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Infinite Universes
Infinite Possibilities
One Dark Fate…

…your breath is loud in the confines of the helmet, and you can feel your pulse battering behind your ear. This is it. In a moment, you will step through the portal into the energy field. You will be the first human being to ever breach the mantle between dimensions. You can feel your hand shaking as you step forward, reaching out for the eternal unknown. You enter the field, and the sensation of shuddering in your belly becomes more violent. Your eyes seem to become wider as a ferocious darkness begins to crowd in upon you, and your skin begins to crawl, as if pulled by a billion hot fish-hooks. Your consciousness begins to fold in upon itself, like surf crashing on a rocky shore. There are things in your mind, things that you were never aware existed. Whispers, presences, sullen, bloated things sluggishly bubbling at the back of your twisted perception. You feel as if your bones are corkscrewing within your body, your blood boiling into a red chilling mist, fingers coiling back upon themselves within the protective suit. Something is watching you, something cold and malevolent, watching and waiting, salivating with a terrible hunger, whispering your name. Your eyes open; the helmet is cracked and there is a breeze hissing through the broken plastic. There is sunlight in your eyes: the light is red. You try to get to your feet and look around this new world. Earth: but not the earth you left only moments ago. You have survived the first interdimensional transition. You are the first human to have ever shifted from one reality to another. You take a breath and realise that you feel cold. The suit should keep you warm, but your whole body can now feel the breeze upon it. You lift your hand to check the integrity: there is a wave of terror in your heart as you realise that your flesh and the suit have become one. Switching focus to the crack in your helmet, you see a trickle of blood from the damaged portion. The helmet is bleeding. You and the suit have become a single biological entity. The first human to travel to a new reality did not arrive completely human…

When worlds collide reality is no longer trustworthy.

Within this book you will find all the rules needed to create characters and run games within the infinite multiverse. The game provides a comprehensive platform to run any adventure in any genre, be it sci-fi, fantasy, horror, super-hero or cyber-punk. Characters can shift between universes to experience other realities.

Games-Masters can choose to throw characters across the multiverse; one week they are in the old west, the next gothic horror or a future of biotechnological marvels, and the following week? Who knows?

When Worlds Collide is a multi-versal, multi-genre role-playing game. To play, you will need a selection of polyhedral dice (available on-line or at you local hobby store), pencil, paper and some friends.

boardgame.name: Table Pack 18: Haunted House and Tee'd Off
boardgame.description:
User Summary

This pack adds recreations of two pinball tables to Pinball Arcade.

Haunted House was released in 1982 by Gottlieb. As the name suggests, it is set in a Haunted House. It was the first table to have a triple playfield accessible by a single ball. The basement is below the main playfield visible through a clear window and the attic is a raised area to the top-right of the playfield. Eight flippers are used to navigate around the different levels and rooms of the House.

Tee'd Off was released in 1993 by Gottlieb. The aim is to complete rounds of golf to activate various multi-ball modes. Your efforts are hampered by the mischievous Gunther the Gopher, an animated representation of whom appears sits above the back-glass. This is a complex table, with five rounds of golf, each of which need 9 holes to be completed by hitting specific targets (or hitting a 'hole in one').

boardgame.name: Table Pack 19: Class of 1812 and Victory
boardgame.description:
User Summary

This pack adds recreations of two pinball tables to Pinball Arcade.

Class of 1812 was released in 1991 by Gottlieb. The playfield includes an animated, severed hand, chattering teeth and a beating heart! The main aim of the game is to to light all of the Bonus Levels in order to resurrect five characters, known as Stiffs.

Victory was released in 1987 by Gottlieb. The table is themed around motor-racing. It was the first table to have a photo-quality mylar overlay on the playfield, rather than the hitherto standard paint directly on wood. The main aim of the table is to finish the race by completing seven Checkpoints by completing specific shots. Completing checkpoints quickly is the key to a high-score, as completing each checkpoint starts a bonus counting down. At the start of the game, the bonus is 100,000 points, completing the first checkpoint scores the current bonus and resets the countdown to 200,000, and so on with the bonus increasing for each checkpoint.

boardgame.name: Table Pack 20: Cue Ball Wizard and El Dorado City of Gold
boardgame.description:
User Summary

This pack adds recreations of two pinball tables to Pinball Arcade.

Cue Ball Wizard was released in 1992 by Gottlieb. The game is themed around playing a game of Billiards in a Western bar. The playfield features a full-size cue-ball. The main aim of the game is to complete six wagon-wheel objectives. These range from 'Rowdy Ramp' which gives 17 seconds to shoot the Ramp as many times as possible, to 'Spell Double' which requires all the letters in D-O-U-B-L-E to be collected. Interestingly, the letters carry over from ball-to-ball and indeed game-to-game. Completing all the wagon-wheel objectives activates Pool Ball Mania, a 3-ball multiball mode. At the conclusion of Pool Ball Mania, 9-Ball Play can be activated. Hitting 7 drop targets in order, collecting the 8-ball and then the 9-ball drop target scores half a billion points - or one billion points if D-O-U-B-L-E is lit!

El Dorado City of Gold was released in 1984 by Gottlieb. The table has an exploration, adventure theme as you search for treasure in the jungle. The gameplay is classic, with the main aim to increase the bonus and multiplier by completing two banks of Drop Targets, and to obtain Specials (extra balls).

boardgame.name: Greed
Szmal
boardgame.description:
In the card game Greed, crime lords (the players) try to earn more money than anyone else through clever use of their cards.

At the start of the game, each player receives a random hand of twelve cards from a deck of 80. Players draft one card, pass the remaining cards left, draft a second card, pass again, draft a third card, pass again, then the game changes; players simultaneously choose and reveal a card, carrying out its effects, then they draft another card, pass the remaining cards, play again, and so on until ten "playing" rounds have passed, at which point the game ends and players tally their holdings.

The card types are thugs, holdings and actions. Thugs and holdings might have a cost to be played (perhaps cash paid to the bank or the discarding of a holding) or a condition that you must meet (having two thugs, for example, or a collection of symbols on cards in your possession) in addition to an effect, which is unique to each card. (Each action has a unique effect as well.) When you play a holding with one or more symbols, you place a token on that card for each symbol on it and an additional token for each symbol of that type already in your possession. These tokens are worth $10k each at the end of the game, and you add this value to whatever cash you've collected through your card plays.

boardgame.name: With Ketchup
boardgame.description:
Dragons like Knights, and Knights like Dragons... With ketchup!

2 players face off, one as the Dragon, and one as the Knight.
Winner of 2 out of 3 battles between 3 (or 4) unique match-ups of a Dragon and a Knight. Is it the Plate armored Knight vs the Hatchling Dragon, or the peasant wearing Quilted armor vs the Ancient Dragon? You won't know until you flip your Armor Cards!

Each player has 4 levels of protection (Armor) as well as Effort cards and Weapon Cards.
The Knight can attack with a [Mighty] and [Good] Effort with his [Razor Sharp] [Halberd] for 11 points, or if his hand is full of weak cards, he'll be forced to make a [Pitiful] Effort to attack with his [Crossbow] for 2 points.
What to play, what to hang on to? Deceptively simple, with a deeper strategy.

Whoever defeats their opponent by reducing their Health to zero in combat will have dinner when they're done.

boardgame.name: TP'd
boardgame.description:
You and your friends have sneaked onto the Johnson's property, and now it's time to TP their trees!

Each player has a picture mat with a Tree on it, and a complete deck of TP/Hazard cards. Your goal is to TP as much of the tree as possible before the cops show up, while dealing with Hazards which will remove your TP.

A Deck contains 2 complete games; 2 Play mats and 2 complete decks of cards with different colored backs to help identify which deck they belong to.

The game can be played solitaire (using 1 deck and 1 Mat), or versus; each player using a mat, combining the decks into 1 big deck, and playing the Hazards on each other!

Three different color sets are available, allowing up to 6 miscreants to be TP'ing the Johnson's trees at once!

boardgame.name: Bivouac
Chamonix Challenge
Final Assault
boardgame.description:
From the back of the box:

If you're afraid of heights, forget it! You're at the foot of one of the world's highest mountains. Awaiting you are snowy slopes and crevasses, icy glaciers and jagged rockface. Get ready to experience the intensity and elation of one of the most grueling sports ever.

Start by choosing from six treacherous trails. Or practice your skills on the training course first. Then pack your rucksack--carefully. The items you choose are critical to survival. Select departure time and season, and the trek begins.

You'll be tested every step by changes in terrain, weather and your health. You could fall thousands of rocky feet. Or freeze to death in a blizzard. Or you just might be one of the lucky few to plant your flag at the peak.


Three types of challenging terrain on each trail with beginner, intermediate and advanced levels.



Choice of over 50 items to pack in your rucksack, from climbing gear to food supplies.



On screen features include the time, temperature, altitude, and climber's physical condition. Even a safety guide to help in the climb.

boardgame.name: Journey: Wrath of Demons – White Bone Demons Expansion
boardgame.description:
As our Pilgrims cross a desolate and craggy mountain pass, they unknowingly stray into the land of the White Bone Demons. At first, the band meets a few skeletal warriors, possessed bones of a long dead army, risen to serve their Queen. After battling against the more corrupted White Bone Demon forms, the Pilgrims find that their Cleanse Ritual is not so effective against these Demon-possessed skeletons. Finally, the narrow path takes them to the Forbidden White Cave, where the Pilgrims confront Yara, Queen of the White Bone Demon Clan, who realises that this is no ordinary group of mortals. If Yara can eat the flesh of Tripitaka, she can gain immortality, regenerate her flesh and regain her beauty. As she launches her minions into a pitched battle, the fast moving White Bone Demons scuttle across the battlefield and Yara herself joins the fray.

Will Yara’s poisoned attack will be the end of our four travelers? There is more at stake than just the Pilgrims lives. If they can defeat Yara and the White Bone Demon Clan, Tripitaka will recover the second piece of the lost Sutras and will be one step closer to restoring the seal on the Underworld.

As normal for expansions, this is not a standalone product. There will be a rules supplement, but it will be based on the Journey rulebook. You will play with some Map Tiles and Bridge Tiles from Journey and the base rules are the same. But the expansion is more than different shaped playing pieces. The White Bone Demons play very differently to the Bull Demons, being faster and harder to cleanse. Faster means it is easier for the Pilgrims to get overrun. With the Cleanse Ritual being less effective, Pilgrims will have to risk more kills and Bad Karma. You will need new strategies to defeat the White Bone Demons.

Finally, there is a new game mechanic. The White Bone Demons are the reanimated bones of long dead warriors. Demon Spirits possess the bones and over time, warp them in to horrific shapes. This separation between the Demon’s spirit and the warrior’s body may explain why the Cleanse Ritual is harder, but it is certainly the explanation of the biggest surprise the Pilgrims will face. Dead White Bone Demons are left on the board and if Yara can attract another Demon Spirit, these piles of bones may spring back to life!

boardgame.name: A Wolf in Sheep's Clothing
boardgame.description:
Two players are prospective sheep farmers aiming to herd the most Sheep from a Flock.

Every turn, players will choose one card from their hand and play it face-down in a Flock, while saying "bah" for each Sheep on the card. Players can choose to tell the truth or lie about how many Sheep there actually are. Once there are seven or more "bah"s said between all players, a player can summon the Dog and say "bark, bark, bark!" If there's no Wolf, the player can pick up the Flock and check for the Wolf. If there's no Wolf, the player can harvest some Sheep, getting them closer to victory, or if there's a Wolf, it has eaten some Sheep! Players can also accuse one another for playing the Wolf, with game-altering consequences. Accumulate 9 sheep during the game and you win!

boardgame.name: Ophir
boardgame.description:
Ophir is a pick up and deliver, set collection game set in an ancient, prosperous world for 2-4 players. In Ophir, you're an influential person of government, trade, or religion with a singular focus - the construction of the Temple.

The Temple is built layer by layer through collective contributions of Silver and Gold. These precious metals are delivered by your merchant ship for Victory Points at the Temple, one of the seven locations you'll be visiting in Ophir.

To afford these precious building materials, you must navigate the region's seas against your rivals to collect goods to fulfill the demand at the Market for Coins, or exchange them for Favor at the Temple.

Well-timed trades, efficient cargo storage, and tactical transportation will be the keys to your success. But you must be swift in your travels, because the game ends immediately once the construction of the Temple is complete. Will it be you whose name is spoken alongside the stories of Ophir's wonder?

With its approachable map and exclusion of direct conflict, Ophir has a familiar and accessible atmosphere that families will enjoy. But with its modular setup, exclusive player roles, and mercurial market, Ophir has tactics, replayability, and tension for experienced gamers to savor!

boardgame.name: Chikken
boardgame.description:
Chikken is a game of dice, risk, strategy, and luck. It's designed for two to six players of any age, as long as they can understand how to make matches with dice.

The goal is to get as high a score as possible without losing your turn. To do this, you roll five special dice (four white, one red), each with one side blank. The red die is called the "Danger Die." If at any time you roll all white blanks, or you roll a red blank, your turn ends without scoring.

You score points by making three/four/five-of-a-kind matches or a straight (1-2-3-4-5). After each roll, you can stop and bank your points (gaining bonus points for matches, plus the total of all spots on the dice), or you can set aside dice of your choice and reroll what's left. However, you MUST set aside any blank white dice after each roll.

An added element of risk management comes when you have a bonus score available, such as from four-of-a-kind. When you do, you have the extra choice of hanging onto those bonus points and rerolling all five dice, with the bonus score still in jeopardy if you should roll blanks and lose your turn. This lets you "start over" with a higher starting value, but all the same risks of losing your turn.

Educational Value

Chikken teaches kids to understand and analyze risks. For younger kids, it's a matching game, and for slightly older ones, they can count up spots, or add up the numbers as they go. And it's still fun for everyone!

boardgame.name: Onmitsu
boardgame.description:
Onmitsu is a Print-and-Play "small card" game. Besides the rules, the whole game is contained in one 54-card deck of cards.

In Onmitsu, you are a spy – an Onmitsu – a sort of spy slash messenger slash ninja slash espionage secret kind of sneak. Your job is to deliver a scroll with a message to your Lord’s boss, the Daimyo. You have a sealed scroll – but so does everyone else. Nobody knows how has which one, either.

Only one message is the “real” message. Others are decoys (which need to be delivered, but aren’t worth as much) and at least “Poison” scroll – a scroll with a hidden message to kill the bearer. Someone doesn’t trust you very much…

Your job is to not only deliver the scroll, but figure out which one you and the other players have. You can always crack yours open to find out, but if the Daimyo shows up before you repair it (or pass it off on some other spy) you are in trouble.

Game play is simple – you draw and discard to form a hand of cards, each of which can be Locations or People. All of them give you the ability to perform actions like steal cards, repair broken scrolls, gain intelligence, or other forms of intrigue.

You win by having the most points, earned by delivering the most important scroll, accumulating cards, and not being the messenger who gets killed.

boardgame.name: Feudalizm
boardgame.description:
Feudalizm is a strategy game set in a medieval atmosphere. The player takes on the role of a local prince and expanding the power of subordinate lands. The game offers a wide range of possible actions: construction of castles, towns, cities and rural location, construction of business facilities, trade, sieges and assaults of castles or towns. The action is varied random events in the form of cards. The modular system allows the board to change its appearance at each game.

Each player starts the game with the disposal of city, a sum of money, a certain amount of raw materials and the deployment of troops and several farm buildings. The player's task is to manage the development of his principality by building new business facilities, colonize new areas, increasing the strength of the army, the establishment of villages and towns, castles extension locks. The main objective pursued by each of the players is dominance over its rivals, which can be obtained on how the economic or military conquering lands belonging to the opponents.

The game is divided into rounds, each round corresponds to one seasonal: spring, summer, autumn, winter. During each turn a player can perform up to four specific actions. The game ends when one player has to fulfill the conditions of economic or military dominance over their opponents.

The basic raw materials present in the game are : wood , stone , ore, iron , food , horses, consumer goods , and weapons and armor .

The game includes a deck of 30 cards random discovered alternately by the players. There are also so-called card . advisors drawn or selected before the start of the game . Features counselors have a significant impact on the course of the game.

The currency of the game are known. kordyty denominations of 1 , 2, 5 and 10 Outbuildings, workers, settlers , towns and villages are in the form of cardboard chips. Castles in the discretion of the buyer may be in the form of chips or resin models.

In choosing the path of military conquest available to the player are various units : light and heavy cavalry , infantry peasant, municipal police, swordsmen, axemen, halberdiers, archers, crossbow and machine battle . Battles can be resolved in a very fast manner (for the impatient players) , or on the board battle (for players with a strategic verve ).


Jest to gra osadzona w klimacie średniowiecza. Gracz wciela się w rolę lokalnego księcia i rozbudowuje potęgę podległych sobie ziem. Gra oferuje szerokie spektrum możliwych akcji: budowa zamków, grodów, lokacja miast i wsi, budowa obiektów gospodarczych, handel, oblężenia i szturmy zamków lub grodów. Akcję urozmaicają wydarzenia losowe w postaci kart. Modułowy układ planszy pozwala zmieniać jej wygląd przy każdej rozgrywce.

Każdy z graczy rozpoczyna grę mając do dyspozycji gród, pewną sumę pieniędzy, określoną ilość surowców i oddziałów wojska oraz kilka obiektów gospodarczych. Zadaniem gracza jest kierowanie rozwojem swego księstwa poprzez budowanie nowych obiektów gospodarczych, kolonizowanie nowych terenów, zwiększanie siły armii, zakładanie wsi i miast, rozbudowa grodów w zamki. Głównym celem do którego dąży każdy z graczy jest dominacja nad rywalami, którą można uzyskać na sposób gospodarczy lub militarny podbijając tereny należące do przeciwników.

Gra podzielona jest na tury, każda tura odpowiada jednemu sezonowi: wiosna, lato, jesień, zima. Podczas każdej z tur gracz może wykonać do czterech określonych czynności. Gra kończy się w chwili gdy jeden z graczy spełni warunki dominacji gospodarczej lub militarnej nad swymi przeciwnikami.

Podstawowe surowce występujące w grze są : drewno , kamień, żelazo , rudy , jedzenie , konie, dobra konsumpcyjne , a broń i zbroje .

Gra zawiera talię 30 kart losowych odkrywanych na przemian przez graczy. Występują również karty tzw. doradców losowane lub wybierane przed rozpoczęciem rozgrywki. Cechy doradców mają istotny wpływ na przebieg gry.

Walutą w grze są tzw. kordyty o nominałach 1, 2, 5 i 10. Budynki gospodarcze, robotnicy, osadnicy, miasta oraz wsie występują w postaci kartonowych żetonów. Grody i zamki w zależności od uznania kupującego mogą być w formie żetonów lub żywicznych modeli.

Obierając drogę militarnego podboju do dyspozycji gracza są różnorakie jednostki: lekka i ciężka jazda, piechota chłopska, straż miejska, miecznicy, topornicy, halabardnicy, łucznicy, kusznicy, oraz machiny bojowe. Bitwy rozstrzygane mogą być w sposób bardzo szybki (dla niecierpliwych graczy), lub na planszy bitewnej (dla graczy z zacięciem strategicznym).

boardgame.name: Wunderteam
boardgame.description:
Two or four player soccer game using metal miniatures; players each have 1 field player and 1 goalie, using a ball that position determines the possession/active player. On a board with checkerboard patterns different areas (dark & light) determine who's next to kick (dark or light team).

The player puts the field kicker next to the ball and releases its leg to kick the ball. The other player should try to block the kick with his/her goal keeper. After the kick the possession is once more decided and the same procedure starts all over again.

Goalies can be managed by two other players, game lasts 2 x 10 minutes.

Remarks: Game was produced during 1930's; 'Wunderteam' was a specific name for the Austrian national soccer team during the years 1931 up to 1933.

boardgame.name: Collision
boardgame.description:
Collision is a super-hero deck building game, created by Magenic Technologies. In Collision, players play as software superheroes (The Automator, The Architect, The Oracle, Big Data, and The Mechanic) to build a deck utilizing additional heroes, super-powers, gear, and additional equipment to fight villains big and small, from small bugs all the way up to the evil Retrograde and Rain Cloud.

On each turn, the active player plays cards from their hands. Most cards in the game yield from 1 to 5 power, which is the main currency of the game. Other cards allow manipulation of the player's discard pile, drawing additional cards, ridding the deck of unwanted cards or additional bonuses. Having accumulated power during their turn, players finally use their power to purchase additional cards to increase their deck's strength. Each card purchased is worth victory points, and the person who has the most victory points at the end of the game is the winner!

boardgame.name: Terra Mystica: Acrylic Overlay Set
boardgame.description:
First edition

This laser cut accessory fits precisely over the top of your faction player mat, providing spaces for each building, power disc bowl, ship and shovel level. In addition, each overlay comes with an innovative interchangeable corner section allowing for the 2 “special” factions that are dramatically different than the others.

Each set is comprised of 5 Bases, 5 standard Faction Corners, and 1 each of Mermaid and Fakir Faction Corners. All of the components are laser cut from 3mm Acrylic and may contain a protective film/paper on one or both sides that is easily removed.

- - - We have been made aware of thickness variability in the production process of Acrylic. Normally this would not be an issue as each overlay or tracker was its own independent entity. However, with this overlay implementing interchangeable parts it is conceivable that you might notice it. Even though we are attempting to cut each set from the same sheet, the variations still persist, so there really isn't anything to be done except let you know about the potential cosmetic inconsistencies. - - -

boardgame.name: Codex of the New Earth: The Cult of the Wraith
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

He Who Sees, Lord of the Watchers.

Among the maddened courts of the Crazed the Wraith is riddle even to his foes. For two hundred years Solomon Nkwame has fought an unending battle against his demented peers, his loyal Watchers striking from the fog of precognitive invisibility and maiming rival cults with secrets stolen from within their own ranks. Does the Wraith truly seek to liberate the New Earth from the scourge of the Crazed, or does he merely desire a world scraped clean of his rivals?

In the Cult of the Wraith you will learn of Nkwame's polymorphic past and get the tools you need to decide his own role in your game. Is he a valiant protector from a lost age, a bringer of knowledge and freedom from the agonies of the Crazed? Or is he only a more seductive kind of lunatic, a deceiver who lures his minions in with hopes to feed their desperate desires? Design the Wraith's back story to suit your own game and let your players discover the truth as best they can.

Inside, you'll find...

Details on Solomon Nkwame, the mysterious Crazed known as the Wraith.
Information on his secretive cult and the forbidden training in psychic mastery that they offer the desperate outcasts of the New Earth.
Statistics for his cult members and the arch-psion himself.
The nullifying art of Abnegation, a brand-new psionic discipline to use in your own game.


Cult of the Wraith is written for the Other Dust post-apocalyptic role-playing game, but its contents are fully compatible with the free Stars Without Number role-playing game, including a section on using the Wraith in your far-future campaign.

boardgame.name: The House of Bone & Amber
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Streets of Paraku Groan....

A furious priest shouts curses from the Shrine of the Seven Red Miracles, and the merchants mutter of thieving Nebeti and their damnable ways. The Nebeti elder lies dead by the amber pits, and the Oba struggles to contain the anger of his people. Old grudges are rising, old hates are waxing strong, and the good people of Paraku fear that the streets will soon run red. Who will help them break the grip of the vengeance that even now rises with fire and spear?

In this new adventure for Spears of the Dawn and other old-school games, characters of levels 1-3 face the fury of a divided city and the scars of a wound that even now threatens the people of Paraku.

The House of Bone and Amber gives the details of the jungle city of Paraku and its stern people. Within you will find a fully-developed city for your game, along with the hidden temples, dungeons, and blasphemous libraries of the fallen House itself. Thrill to the grim tale of the green stone bowl and the doom it threatens upon the bitter city and discover for yourself the awful fate that awaits its people. Heroes are needed in this burdened land, brave souls to strengthen the hands of the good citizens of Paraku and break the knives of those who would welcome a dawn of smoke and blood.

While The House of Bone and Amber is designed for level 1-3 characters created with Spears of the Dawn, a conversion guide provides for a quick and easy transposition of the module into your own favorite old-school rule system. Along with that convenience, the module has been designed to be easily sliced apart into urban details, local NPCs, and long-buried levels of the House itself for you to recycle and repurpose for you own game worlds. Even after your mighty heroes have faced the grim green doom of the city, you can easily strip out the levels and city portions they never touched to help compose their next thrilling tale!

boardgame.name: Portes, Monstres & Trésors (1st Edition)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Vous êtes un incurable nostalgique qui garde telle une relique sa précieuse "boîte rouge", un jeune rôliste curieux de savoir à quoi jouaient les Anciens, ou tout simplement quelqu'un qui veut un jeu de rôle médiéval-fantastique simple mais complet ? Portes, Monstres & Trésors est fait pour vous !
Ce jeu complet et gratuit en version PDF est une traduction et une adaptation du contenu en Licence Ludique Libre de Labyrinth Lord, jeu écrit par Daniel Proctor et édité par Goblinoid Games. Comme son modèle, PMT émule les mécanismes de la version B/X de D&D (celle parue en 1981). Les connaisseurs remarqueront que nous avons rajouté deux règles optionnelles : le jet de sauvegarde unique et la classe d'armure ascendante.

Pourquoi ne pas avoir fait une VF officielle de Labyrinth Lord ?
Tout simplement parce que les négociations avec Daniel Proctor au sujet de la licence Labyrinth Lord n'ont pas abouti. L'essentiel de Labyrinth Lord (le texte et les cartes) est sous Licence Ludique Libre, mais pas la marque "Labyrinth Lord" et la mise en page : c'est pourquoi nous avons dû adopter une nouvelle mise en page et trouver un nouveau nom pour cette traduction.


Translation:You are an incurable nostalgic that keeps their relic like the precious "red box", a young gamer curious to know what the elders played, or just someone who wants a simple but complete medieval fantasy role playing games? Portes, Monstres & Trésors (Doors, Monsters & Treasures) is for you!
This free and complete game published as a PDF is a translation and adaptation of the Open Gaming Licensed Labyrinth Lord, written by Daniel Proctor and published by Goblinoid Games. As a model, PMT emulates the mechanisms of the B/X version of D&D (the one published in 1981). Connoisseurs will notice that we have added two optional rules: the unique saving throw and increasing armor class.

Why not make an official French version of Labyrinth Lord?
Just because negotiations with Daniel Proctor on the Labyrinth Lord license have failed. While most of Labyrinth Lord (text and maps) is Open Gaming Licensed, the brand "Labyrinth Lord" and the layout are not, which is why we have adopted a new layout and found a new name for this version.

Robin Hood and his gifted team of young vigilantes must help the downtrodden people of their land and deal with evil plots of the Sheriff – before finally meeting up with the villain himself in a final showdown to decide the fate of the Nottingham Sector.

boardgame.name: Armies of the Dead
boardgame.description:
Each player starts with four dice of each of six types (d4, d6, d8, d10, d12, and d20), and the first to lose all twenty-four dice loses the game. Each battle is different according to the terrain dice thrown, which determine how many and which dice may battle, if any are modified/doubled, and how many actions each player may take per turn. Each type of die has basic abilities (resurrection/banishment, mimicry, split attacks, join-forces, re-roll opponent die/dice, re-roll own die/dice), and all but the d4 have special abilities activated by rolling pairs (or more) of the same number.

The player with initiative (usually lower total roll) takes one, two, or three actions (based on the throw of the terrain dice) before the opponent has a chance to respond. Actions include one die attacking another or activating abilities, or activating abilities and then attacking an opponent's die (most common).

There is a balance between thinking through the possibilities and over-thinking what your opponent may do, particularly in the selection of which dice to roll at the beginning of each battle. Each battle will consist of different combinations of dice, resulting in different abilities interacting, keeping the game fresh and interesting throughout.

boardgame.name: Cabals: The Board Game
boardgame.description:
The First World War is over and it is time to choose your side. Underground secret societies, or rather cabals, are battling for world domination. Containing spies, witches, faeries, magicians and other creatures from all over the world you must select your cabal wisely.

Cabals: The Board Game brings together key deck building mechanics with board control in a new battle that can either be won through board domination or conquering the opponents stronghold. Once the battleground has been constructed the luck of the draw and your deck building skills dictate what creatures you have at your disposal. Units battle one another backed up by spells and lead by a single hero for your deck from one of the four cabals.

The turn sequence comprises of gaining domination points, gaining resources, drawing cards, the main strategic phase (containing combat) and ending your turn. Resources dictate what cards you can use and this combined with loyalty points (depending on the cabals and their allegiances) the player has a deep, strategic game to conquer on many levels. The game is based on the digital Cabals: Magic & Battle Cards and these same key mechanics prevail but this version has more streamlined gameplay suitable to a tabletop game.

Two fleets fight against each other during the game. Their aim is to destroy the enemy’s Command Ship. However this is a hard challenge because the game offers several options to obstruct or threaten the enemy’s vessels. Planting sharp mines in the route of the ships is one of them, or you may choose to bluff and plant fake mines that look exactly like real ones...

How does it play?

- Every turn the active player rolls a die. The die shows how many actions you have to take in your round: 1, 2 or 3.
- After you roll, you can plant mines on empty fields if you want.
- Now choose a ship and spend your actions. Turn, move or shoot. Every ship type has its unique weapons, and specific role in the battle.
- The first player who hits their opponent's Command Ship is the winner.

What this game offers:

- short, simple, easy-to-understand rules,
- quick set up, no more than 5 minutes after the second game,
- relatively short rounds (30-45 minutes), no time to get bored.

Adventure hook for use with this product.

The Awakening: While traveling in the forest, the group comes upon a gathering of men and women with black robes having green and brown embroidered trims. They are chanting loudly and praying towards the pillars and statues. It is up to the group to investigate or interfere with the ritual if they wish. If the group interferes, the cultists scatter. If the group tries to take the sword, the hand statues awaken and attack the group to stop them from stealing the sword.

If the group waits, the cultists finish their ritual. The hand statues pull up a massive body from underneath the ground below, the earth swallowing up many of the surprised cultists. The hands attach to the four pillars, clicking into place. Two of the hands act as legs, two as arms, and the other hand is where a head would be. The cultist leader then directs the massive statue to head towards the nearest town… Its up to the group to then stop the massive monster directly or try and defeat the leader of the cultists, hoping that it stops the statue’s rampage.

boardgame.name: Inertia
boardgame.description:
Inertia is a game of unification in the sense of Claude Soucie's Lines of Action. The first player to unite all of his pieces on the board into a single group wins.

To start, white places one piece anywhere on the 8x8 square board. Players then alternate placing pieces on the board, with the first piece being adjacent to the opponent's most recently placed piece and the second piece being adjacent to no pieces, either orthogonally or diagonally.

Once a player can't place a second piece, the placement phase ends and the next player starts the movement phase. On a turn, a player moves one piece akin to a queen in chess, with movement ending after passing through any number of empty spaces or by landing on an opponent's piece and capturing it. If this move increases the total number of groups on the board — with a group being a single stone or a series of straight- or diagonally-connected like-colored stones — then the move is illegal. Gameplay continues until one player unites all of his pieces into a single group; if he simultaneously creates single groups for both players, then the game is a draw.

Instead of using a chess board, Inertia can be played on a hexhex board with pieces moving like hex rooks.

boardgame.name: Overlords: The Card Game
boardgame.description:
The evil empire is divided. Amidst the chaos, several overlords emerge to claim rule over all by raising great armies of hellish creatures. They all yearn for power but only one will emerge victorious.

Overlords is a set collection, card drafting game for 2-4 players. Each turn, players recruit one card from their hand and then pass the rest of their hand to the player on their left. Every time a card is recruited, it goes into that player’s army pile. Only the top card is visible in each player’s army at any given time. There are two types of cards available in the game—Monster cards and Hired Hand cards. Each Monster card has a unique scoring mechanism. Players must recruit them wisely in order to maximize the amount of points of their army. Hired hand cards are placed separate from an army and, when activated, have special abilities that affect the game. The player who raises the most powerful army, wins! .

Overlords easily plays under 20 minutes. The game is simple to teach, yet tough to master. There is even a 2 vs 2 option that allows for some interesting team play.

boardgame.name: Sòcc'mel
boardgame.description:
A trick-taking card game focusing on expressions from Bologna's dialect. Players try to avoid taking suits of unlucky events going around the table by either adding a more powerful event of the same sphere, or trumping the suit with an event of a different sphere (the three spheres being home, work or street). If not avoidable, the trick taking can be mitigated by playing a swear word card, or by a Socc'mel card, which transfer the suit to another player. Goal of the game is pushing the other players anger-meter ("incazzometro") beyond 10 to eliminate them from the game.

The game is marketed for ages 6 up, with the explicit proviso that obscenities from Bologna are widely accepted and not considered offensive (which is the case, to some extent...).

boardgame.name: Subterfuge
boardgame.description:
Subterfuge is a 2-player, luck-free, abstract strategy game played on a standard chess /checkers board using 12 standard dice (6 each in 2 separate colours).

The game has many similarities to chess but uses d6 dice as the pieces. Each player starts with their 6 dice in their home territory and they advance into the field to play. Players alternate moving one of their pieces with the winner being the first player to capture 4 of their opponent’s pieces.

The value of each die face determines the movement and capability of the piece – smaller values move lesser distances but can Capture larger dice – higher value dice move greater distances but Expose smaller dice - equal value dice Influence the value of neighbouring dice, including your own. Pieces may move forward or backward according to the movement rules defined for each die facing.

Stuterfuge includes many layers of strategic play and brain-burning tactical play, as the dice values change throughout the game. Game length can vary between 15 to 60 mins, depending on the time permitted for each move. Multiple variants are also included in the rules, allowing wildly different tactics and play for each game.

boardgame.name: Millennium Blades
千年之刃
boardgame.description:
Millennium Blades is a CCG-Simulator -- A game in which you play as a group of friends who play the fictional CCG "Millennium Blades".

In this game you will build decks, play the meta, acquire valuable collections, crack open random boosters, and compete in tournaments for prizes and fame. The game takes you from Starter Deck to Regionals in about 2-3 hours.

Multiple games can also be chained together to form a Campaign, going from Regionals to Nationals in game 2 and from Nationals to Worlds in game 3, with each game introducing ever more powerful cards and higher stakes, but also resetting the power of the game so that each player has a fair chance to win each 'season' of the campaign.

The game draws heavily on Manga/Anime inspiration for its art, and parodies Magic: the Gathering, Yugioh, and many other collectible games.

At its heart, it’s a commodity trading game, except that instead of cubes or stocks, the things you’ll be buying, selling, and speculating on are trading cards that can be used throughout the game in periodic tournaments. By trading wisely, playing the market, working together with friends, building collections, and winning tournaments, you’ll secure points and become the Millennium Blades World Champion.

The game features a system of card pods, where you will play with about 400 of the base game’s 600 cards every game.

boardgame.name: Celebrity
Знаменитость
boardgame.description:
"Znamenitost" means Celebrity in Russian. It's a quiz game with a unique mechanic that provides infinite questions, and you don't need a game master to play it.

There are 4 different kinds of decks (24 cards per deck, 96 total).
1. Facts: each card represents a fact from a biography (for example, "She wrote a book", "Something is named after her", "She was imprisoned", etc.).
2. Professions, such as "politician", "actor", "soldier", etc.
3. Alphabet: each card is a letter, which should be the first letter of someone's name, surname, pseudonym, or nick name.
4. Countries, such as "USA", "Germany", or "Russia".

Each round one of the players chooses a deck, reveals the top card and reads its text aloud. Then everybody tries to name a famous person that matches the task of the card. The fastest player reveals the top card of one of the remaining decks, and now the players try to name the person who matches two criteria, and so on.

For example, if the cards "C" and "She wrote a book" were revealed, it's possible to name Julius Caesar, Winston Churchill, Clive Barker, or any other person with the first "C" in his/her name (or surname, or nickname) and known as an author. If nobody could name a person after the next card was revealed, than the player who had correctly named the previous person wins a round. You cannot reveal more than 4 cards (one per deck): if someone has managed to name a person with 4 cards, he wins that round.

The game is played till one of the decks is depleted.

Contents:
96 cards (24 per deck)
2 blank cards for your own tasks
rules

boardgame.name: The Tower of Dr. Alienstein (Revised)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:



Generic Adventure Location for Your Role Playing Game

Its Alive-Alive!

A creepy, crumbling tower sits out in the middle of nowhere, surrounded by a run-down graveyard. Loud laughter erupts from the confines of the shadowed place. Thunder cracks and lightning crackles, drawn to electrical rods on the roof. In that moment of brilliaqnt light all manner of horrors are glimpsed: strange, abominations shambling about the grave yard, a hulking brute on the roof; and a tall, pale alien thing in a lab coat. As the rain pouds down. You check your weapons and move in.

Get ready for frightfully creepy entertainment, as the players in your role playing game must confront the uncanny horrors of this unique location, rich with campy creatures and sinister alien plots. It is timeless pulp, fitting for the late Victorian through today. The game includes gamemaster maps of each level, descriptions of abominations and the masters of the tower, Dr.
Viktor Shelley and the menacing Dr. Alienstein. The book is generic and easily adaptable to most games, but just in case, we have included an alternative skill system and conversion tables so that you may more easily bring this hide-away of horrors to your gaming table. Need some unusual twists, we have included the Cosmic Eye; a series of tables to help you find inspiration and keep your ideas fresh and lively...er, well...un-lively…anyway. Easy to use comparative tables help to describe how the ranks in the game measure up to the real world.

The characters are easily adapable, with their conditions and abilities described in simple terms. You will be up and running in minutes. Have a blast and well...break a leg. Don't leave it behind; there is no telling what Dr. Alienstein might do with it.


Good Horror Stories Always Have Sequels

There are over 25 Story Hooks to Keep Your Characters Guessing. Our story hooks provide you with inspiration and alternatives for what type of story you may want to run. These story hooks, range from the macrabre to the kooky.


What this Book Contains


Four Levels of the tower, one sub-level, and the roof
Descriptions of Dr. Viktor Shelley, Dr. Alienstein, the Creature; and a group of undead, scientifically augmented monstrosities.
Over 25 story hooks to keep the stories coming
The Cosmic Eye, a collection of tables that make answering simple questions a lot more fun
Comparative Tables to gain real perspective of what the simple ranking system means
Conversion tables for converting the generic ranking system for statistics to other common dice mechanics


It's Like a play set for RPGs. The Tower of Doctor Alienstein is a generic product, intended to be dropped into a pre-existing campaign. All descriptions and statistics are given in broad, easily adaptable terms.

Weirdly horrific, this book will quickly be one of your favorites. Definatly an adventure location that will be talked about again and again.

boardgame.name: Pit of Pillars
boardgame.description:
Pit of Pillars is an elimination game of placement of men, and moving and capturing stacks. Every capture results in a pillar being erected on the square where the capture took place. Pillars belong to the captor and move as chess queens. They can neither capture nor move over pieces.

Stacks can be split or joined. Whether a stack is vulnerable to capture is determined by the number of adjacent squares. Pillars take away such squares and thus heighten vulnerability of adjacent stacks.

A player wins by eliminating all of the opponent's stacks from the board (regardless of any reserves either player might have in hand) or by leaving his opponent without a legal move. Cooperative cycles are inherently possible, but in regular play the game will seldom end in a draw.

The game can be played using simple generic material: a chess board, draughtsmen, and chess pawns to represent pillars.

boardgame.name: Jaywalkers
boardgame.description:
Jaywalkers is a two player game, played on the spaces of a 8x8 board.

2 pawns in two colors and 62 path tiles.

SETUP - Place board between players, pawns start on any space of each player’s respective first rows.

PLAY – A player on his turn must take two actions.

1.Place a tile onto an empty space.
2.Move your pawn in a series of one or more rook moves over any number of tiles following any one of three paths shown on a tile you're currently moving over and ending the move on an empty space.

RESTRICTIONS – The tile you placed on your turn must be part of the route your pawn takes. A pawn may not land on a tile. Your pawn may not jump over your opponent's pawn.

ENDGAME – You win if your opponent is unable to take his two actions.

boardgame.name: Shadow Societies
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Most creatures that come to the attention of the Order are lone predators or members of a small pack or cult. They may be dangerous adversaries – red in tooth and claw, or wielding foul sorceries – but they tend to be isolated threats. They lack the co-ordination and resources guardian priests can bring to bear. Such enemies are dealt with swiftly and without mercy.

In recent years, however, it has become apparent to the Masters of the Order that other forces are at work in the world. These are not just mindless monsters or heretical rabbles but organised and purposeful groups whose powers are not to be underestimated and whose goals are dark and fathomless.

As always, the Order must respond. It must adapt and counter these new challenges, in order to see His Will done and Christendom protected.

But can the truth be uncovered in time? And even then, can mortal man hope to stand against such ageless adversaries when, for so long, they have gone about their work undetected?

Presented within this book are details of some of the mysterious groups whose activities threaten not just Christendom but the world itself. Many of these organisations are centuries old, with schemes and ambitions set to play out in the years ahead. They can provide even experienced guardian priests with new and diverse challenges – and move the events of a Deus Vult campaign far beyond the relative safety of northern Europe to the Holy Lands and beyond. For, just as the Order is increasingly aware of these shadowy groups, so they too are taking a greater interest in the warriors of the Mont St. Michel.

These include Malik Dhukan, the exiled King of the Djinn; strange were-races of the Scions of Zeus; and mysterious eastern sorcerers from far Cathay.

But fear not brothers and sisters, for ours is a divine calling and we shall not be alone. Strike out into the darkness.

boardgame.name: Illegal
boardgame.description:
Description
ILLEGAL is a crazy, offbeat party game for 5 to 9 players where participants each take on the role of an illegal dealer. The game is accessible to casual as well as expert gamers, and has a mature theme. The rules of ILLEGAL are simple, but the game will challenge your skills in negotiation, misdirection, discretion, charisma, and persuasion. The more you play, the more you will learn to expand and master these skills. Each game lasts about half an hour, and is packed with intense exchanges, interactions and a lot of humour.

Launch into this risqué adventure! Dare to become one of these offbeat dealers and get a good laugh with your friends.

How to Play

ILLEGAL is played in two phases:

During the first phase, each player receives a deck of cards prepared by the Game Master (GM). These decks assign each player his dealer role and gives him a good quantity of the corresponding resources. Each player's deck also specifies his buyer role, and he will make every effort during the game to get as many resources as possible of the type he is interested in. These roles are kept secret until the end of the game.

Players leave the table and split up into continually changing pairs or groups to negotiate and exchange some of their resources, away from prying eyes. Every three minutes, they return to the table to collect new resources at the docks (from the GM). Then they go again for another three minutes of secret dealing.

The second phase, called the Tribunal phase, starts once the players have returned to the table and the GM has run out of resources.

At the tribunal, players play the roles of jury members, witnesses, suspects and judges! They openly discuss their suspicions concerning the secret roles assigned to every other player. The GM reveals the suspect cards in pairs representing the dealer and buyer roles assigned to the various players. For each card pair, players have one minute to debate. After one minute, a simultaneous vote is cast, and a suspect is formally accused.

Scoring

At the end of the game, each player reveals his role pair and acquired resources. He scores one victory point for each resource acquired corresponding to his buyer role, one point for each suspect card accusing him wrongly, thus rewarding him for his skills in misdirection and discretion, but he loses 5 points for each suspect card accurately accusing him, representing 5 years spent in prison. It is very easy to end the game with a 10-year jail sentence if you are insufficiently discreet or are too greedy!

Each special space represents faults earned by the rider that round. These fault points have to be written down as they are earned. A slight twist with this game is that the order of finishing also generates time-faults; 1st to finish, none; second to finish, 5 time-faults, and so on.

After all the players have finished, the player with the fewest faults, wins.

A simple roll and move game. Players represent characters from the Disney animated film about Alice in Wonderland.

Roll a 5 to start. When you land on special square they will often tell you how many blackberries you have picked that turn. Record the number so that each player will have a total once all have finished. The player who picks the most, wins.

boardgame.name: Stellar War
boardgame.description:
Stellar War is based on an old Avalon Hill card game known as Naval War, but rather than simulate a war at sea during WWII, Stellar War simulates a war in space, in the distant future.

The object is to have the most points at the end of play, by destroying enemy spaceships and space stations and preserving your own. Each player begins with a fleet of ships and stations used to attack opponents, and plays cards from their hand that represent offensive and defensive actions and other special events. Ships and stations can acquire special defenses or abilities. Optional rules are included to allow different configurations of play.

boardgame.name: Hei Su Hong Su
boardgame.description:
Hei Su Hong Su is a battle of wits between two opponents, played on an elegantly crafted board framed in genuine cherry or mahogany. Each game includes an authentic Chinese i-ching coin. In Hei Su Hong Su, when tokens are moved off one end of the board, they return on the opposite side. Additionally, unlike other popular strategy games, players are permitted to move neutral and their opponent’s tokens as their own. Hei Su Hong Su is truly a unique and intriguing strategy game.

In Hei Su Hong Su, one player is red, other is black. At the start of the game, each player has nine pieces set up in a square in opposite corners on the board, with 18 white pieces occupying the other two corners. Players take turns “sliding” rows or columns of pieces by removing a piece from an edge and adding it to the other edge. If a player traps a piece by surrounding it with 4 of his color (including “wrapping around” to the other side of the board), it is replaced with with one of that player's pieces. If a player captures and replaces a white piece, the “tug of war” marker moves 1 in his favor on the scale. If a player captures and replaces an opponent’s piece, the marker moves 2 in his favor on the scale. The game ends when the marker has moved all the way to the end of the scale; that player is the winner.

boardgame.name: Bigfoot
boardgame.description:
A quick playing card game for two where Bigfoot and the clever Cryptozoologist attempt to outwit each other! Will Bigfoot's hideaways be discovered, leaving him with nowhere to go, or will the Cryptozoologist be left frustrated?

This new game from up and coming designer Scott Almes is the ultimate battle of wits! Depending on what side you're on, you'll be playing a very different game - The Cryptozoologist is laying traps and attempting to trick the Bigfoot who must deduce and work out what's the best option...

One player plays the Cryptozoologist who is hunting for Bigfoot, played by the other player. Each round, the Cryptozoologist will lay out a series of cards in two ‘paths’, which will contain sensing equipment and special actions. Then, Bigfoot must choose which path to go on, triggering any sensing equipment and giving the Cryptozoologist a few more clues about his Lair. The Cryptozoologist wins by pinning Bigfoot in one of his Lairs, while Bigfoot wins by eluding the Cryptozoologist for six rounds. Capturing this beast won't be easy...!

By slowly eliminating the various potential lairs, the Cryptozoologist will slowly whittle down the places where Bigfoot could actually be hiding. However, if this isn't done by the end of the sixth round the beast will escape the clutches of 'science'!

boardgame.name: Io canto
boardgame.description:
Each player chooses a pawn and take the 6 pieces of its color.
Put the pawn chosen at the beginning of the board.
Shuffle the 'unexpected' and 'guests' cards in the appropriate spaces on the board.
Shuffle the 24 cards songs and arrange them in the appropriate spaces on the game board.
Insert the jury card inside the bag. If you play in 5 or 6, put them all, or, in the case of 3 or 4 players, only enter the 8 cards numbered from 1 to 2 .
The players alternate in singing receiving the votes of the public (the other players) and the judgment of the jury.
The game is played in 3 rounds plus a final.

Round 1
The current player draws the card song on top of its pile.
Read the songs and decide whether or not to accept the card, otherwise goes to the player to his left until this is chosen by someone.
If all pass, the card is given to the player who had drawn it.
The player who is assigned the card chooses one of the songs written on the front and draws an "unexpected" card.
The player performs the song choice with track on the CD and respecting the rule reported on the "unexpected".
At the end of the performance each of the other players pass a covered card of values.
The player draws a jury card.
The turn passes to the next player. In the first run you must show all at once.
At the end of the performances the players reveal their cards and advance their pawn based on the score received.

Round 2
In the second round the players are performing in duets.
The player chooses a card from the relative number of bunches . Choose a song and a player with which to perform.
The players perform together.
At the end of the performance the other players place a card deck of their color on one area related to one of the two players who have just sung.
Each of the 2-player draws a card and places the jury in your area.
As in the first run will add up your points and advancing the pawn.

Round 3
The last in the standings takes the bunch of songs for the third exhibition and chooses a card based on the type they prefer, without reading the songs.
Then draw a card guest, choose a song and a famous singer and performs alternating a normal singing voice imitation of the chosen guest.
At the end of the performance the other players place a card deck of their color on the area of ​​the board on the turn player.

Final
The two players with the highest score in the final play.
The cards not used are shuffled. Players draw a card and perform the song. The other players vote.
Players then draw a card jury.
The player with the highest score is the winner.

boardgame.name: Last Night on Earth 'Hold the Line' Game Supplement
boardgame.description:
From Flying Frog's Website:

"The 'Hold the Line' Supplement is a Web-exclusive for 'Last Night on Earth' and features a new scenario and ten new game cards. All pieces are printed on the same high-quality card stock as the boardgame. The cards are exclusive to this supplement and will not be available anywhere else. They feature all new artwork."

boardgame.name: Power Play Scenario Book
boardgame.description:
From the PDF:

"Scenarios are special rule sets that change the game and provide new ways for you to experience Power Play. In this supplement, we’ve collected together 9 exciting and fun ways that you can experience Power Play in a new light. We hope you enjoy them!

Note that these scenarios are designed for players that have already played the core game of Power Play several times, and are ready for new challenges and opportunities to test their wiles against their fellow Outliers.

If rules debates and questions arise during play, remember that you can use a Reality Check to resolve rules disputes in a quick and fair manner.

Have fun!"
